NiMgAlMo catalyst derived from a guest-host MoO4 2- mediated layered double hydroxide: High performance for the methane decomposition reaction Wei Liang Conceptualization Methodology Investigation Writing - original draft Hao Yan Methodology Formal analysis Investigation Xiang Feng Methodology Writing - review & editing Chen Chen Investigation Dong Lin Visualization Jixia Liu Investigation Xiaobo Chen Supervision Funding acquisition Project administration Validation Writing - review & editing * Yibin Liu Writing - review & editing Chaohe Yang Supervision Funding acquisition Validation Honghong Shan Supervision Funding acquisition * State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Qingdao 266580, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum Qingdao 266580 China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, Qingdao 266580, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The synthesis of highly active and stable Ni catalysts for the catalytic decomposition of methane (CDM) reaction is still a challenge. Herein, a MoO4 2− intercalated NiMgAlMo layered double hydrotalcite (LDH) was synthesized. After calcination and reduction, NiMo alloy particles with an average diameter of 7.4 nm were formed and showed good thermal stability. The NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst showed superior hydrogen formation rate of 56 mmol/gNi min compared with the NiMgAl-800 catalyst of 33 mmol/gNi min derived from NiMgAl-LDH. The stability of the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst showed good catalytic stability under 10 times reaction-regeneration cycles. With the aid of multiple characterization techniques, we found that Mo addition could not only improve nickel dispersibility but also facilitate methane adsorption and hydrogen desorption through simulative electron transfer from Mo to Ni, thus enhancing the catalyst activity. The insights and methodology presented here may shed new light on the synthesis of highly dispersed and stable metal catalysts. Keywords Methane decomposition Hydrogen LDH Ni-Mo alloy particles 1 Introduction With the rapid development of the world’s economy, the extensive usage of traditional energy resources, such as fossil fuels, has continuously led to severe environmental pollution and ecological damage [1–3]. On the basis of the International Energy Agency (IEA)’s statistics, the world’s energy demand incur an increase of 30 % by the year 2040, which will be accompanied by the upgrading of the energy structure, especially by substituting coal and oil with alternative, clean and renewable energy sources [4]. Hydrogen, the most abundant element on the planet, is easily identified as a promising energy vector that will be implemented in the near future, which will take advantage of the easily generated and uncontaminated combustion product [5,6]. At present, the world hydrogen consumption is almost 65 million tonnes per year, in which approximately 95 % of this consumption is demanded by carbon-intensive processes, for example, by petroleum refineries and the synthetic ammonia industry [7]. Additionally, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, hydrogen can be applied in fuel cells and engines and is a promising alternative for fossil fuels in the transportation industry in the near future [8]. Considering that the rate of global hydrogen consumption increased annually by approximately 3–4% [9], stable and efficient routes of producing hydrogen with minimal environmental impacts are urgently needed. Hydrogen can be produced by many effective methods, including water electrolysis, thermochemical routes, and biological routes. Due to the current global situation, hydrogen directly generated by thermochemical conversion technologies using fossil fuels (natural gas, oil, and coal) as feedstock is still in the dominant method [10]. Almost 96 % of the global hydrogen demand is satisfied by the steam reforming process and mostly by the reforming of natural gas (48 %) [11]. The industrial process is also known as steam methane reforming (SMR). Although the SMR process is extensively used by industrial applications, the requirement of the CCS (carbon dioxide capture and storage) process has led to a cost increase due to the limitation of CO2 emissions [12]. Comparatively, the catalytic decomposition of methane (CDM) process, during which only pure hydrogen is generated as gaseous product, is recognized as a promising, cost-effective and benign environmental route for producing hydrogen. The life-cycle assessment has revealed that the CDM process not only had a lower energy consumption (37.8 kJ/mol H2) than the SMR process (63.3 kJ/mol H2) [13] but also could decrease the global equivalent CO2 emissions by up to 27 % compared with the current situation [14]. Eq. 1 presents a simplified equation of the CDM process. (1) C H 4 → C s + 2 H 2 ( g ) Δ H r 0 = + 74.6 ( k j / m o l ) The reported equilibrium curve [15] shows that without catalysts, a reaction temperature above 1000℃ is normally required to achieve nearly complete methane conversion. Consequently, appropriate catalysts are highly desired. For methane conversion reactions (SMR, CDM, and the dry reforming of methane (DRM)), Ni-based catalysts were the most widely studied because their CH breaking ability is comparable with that of noble metals and they are relatively inexpensive [16–18]. To obtain a high activity of methane conversion, highly dispersed nickel particles are especially crucial. However, due to the low Tammann temperature of nickel (691 ℃), the sintering of nickel species is inevitable. Thus, the rational selection and appropriate preparation method design of Ni-based catalysts are essential to obtain nickel particles with a high dispersibility and good thermal stability. Hydrotalcite, known as a layered double hydroxide (LDH), is a homogeneously mixed metal compound with a lamellar structure. Hydrotalcite consists of positively charged layers with well-dispersed metal ions and negatively charged anions as well as H2O in the interstitial layers [19]. Based on the structural characteristics of LDH-laminated metal cations with highly dispersed, interlayered and orderly arranged anions, LDH materials have significant advantages when used as a single precursor to prepare heterogeneous catalytic materials with highly dispersed catalytic activity sites by employing lamellar stripping, lattice limiting, and intercalation assembly techniques. The process used to synthesize LDHs is simple; the types and amounts of both the cations on the layers and chelated anions can be randomly modulated within limits. After thermal treatment, the derived stable metal oxide (DMO) usually showed a good catalytic activity toward methane conversion reactions [20–23], especially for application in the methane cracking reaction. For instance, Ashok [24] et al. has synthesized precursors of hydrotalcite-like structures of Ni-Cu-Al catalysts with different Cu/Al ratios by the coprecipitation method. It was observed that the addition of Cu to Ni enhanced the methane decomposition activity when added in appropriate amounts. Guil-Lopez [25] et al. performed a catalytic study of the Ni-catalysts based on Ni/Mg/Al mixed oxides derived from hydrotalcite-like compounds and observed a particular “auto-regeneration” behavior that occurred during the methane decomposition reaction. Nevertheless, the commonly used intercalated anions, for example, CO3 2− and NO3-, would be removed during the calcination step of the catalyst preparation process, resulting in the collapse of the layered structure. The well dispersed metal cations on each layer would aggregate to form large metal species, which was an unavoidable obstacle for applying LDHs as catalyst precursors. Interestingly, LDHs possess a particular property named the “memory effect”, which refers to the ability of a material to recover the original layered structure when the mixed MII (MIII)O oxide, obtained by the mild calcination (500 °C) of the LDH precursor, is immersed in a solution of the anions to be intercalated. By taking advantage of this property, Zhao et al. [26] proposed an effective method to fabricate thermally stable Fe metal nanoparticles, which led to minimal metal sintering, even at 900 ℃, through the calcining of a FeMgAlMo-LDH material synthesized by MoO4 2- intercalation with the aid of the “memory effect”. Except for the lattice restrictions of laminates, the guest-host interaction induced by MoO4 2− has further inhibited metal sintering and promoted dispersion. Well dispersed embedded Fe metal particles with a high density (ranging from 1014 to 1016 m-2) and good thermal stability were obtained by the chemical precursor-mediated formation of the metal NPs on LDH flakes. These Fe NPs were very active for the formation of single-walled nanotube-array double helices at a harsh reaction temperature of 900 °C. Herein, a MoO4 2− intercalated NiMgAlMo-LDH was prepared with the aid of the “memory effect” to prevent the nickel particles from sintering by minimizing the layered structure collapse that occurs during the calcination step. The Ni catalysts derived from calcining the LDHs were evaluated for their catalytic activity in CDM reactions. NiMo alloy particles with an average diameter of 7.4 nm were formed, even with a harsh reduction temperature of 800 ℃, and have exhibited a good thermal stability. The NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst has showed superior activity and good stability as adopted in methane decomposition reaction. The catalyst’s physical properties and reducibility and the Ni particle dispersibility as well as the amount and morphology of the carbon deposits on the spent catalysts were characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), thermogravimetric analysis and so on. Depending on these characterizations, the correlation between the catalytic performance and the catalyst structure was established. The probable formation route of the small NiMo alloy particles is proposed. The promotion effect of Mo addition on the catalyst performance was also revealed by combining TPD characterization with elaborate DFT calculations. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The chemicals used in this work were all of the analytical reagent grade and were used without further treatment. Aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2·6H2O), nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), sodium molybdate dihydrate (Na2MoO4·2H2O) and urea (CH4N2O) were purchased from Sinopham Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All the experimental gases used were supplied by Qingdao Airox Gases & Chemicals Co., Ltd., and each component was 99.999 % pure. 2.2 Synthesis of NiMgAl layered double hydrotalcite The hydrotalcite-type precursor with a Mg/Al molar ratio of 3:1 in the feed was synthesized by a co-precipitation method similar to the one described in the literature [27] by employing urea as the precipitation agent. The hydrolysis of urea could take place at 96 ℃ and was accompanied by the generation of ammonium carbonate so that Mg2+, Al3+, and Ni2+ would precipitate simultaneously. In a typical synthesis procedure, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Mg(NO3)2·6H2O, Al(NO3)3·9H2O and urea were dissolved in 300.0 mL deionized water with [Ni2+]+[Mg2+]+[Al3+] = 0.15 mol/L, n(Mg):n(Al) = 3:1, and [urea] = 3.0 mol/L. The nominal nickel content was 12 wt%. The as-obtained solution was maintained at 96 ℃ in a 500 ml flask for 24 h with vigorous stirring in an ambient atmosphere. After that, the obtained hydrotalcite was filtered and washed with deionized water until the pH of the filtrate was neutral. Finally, the hydrotalcite was treated with freeze-drying. The product was denoted as NiMgAl-LDH. 2.3 Synthesis of MoO4 2−-intercalated layered double hydrotalcite The MoO4 2−-intercalated layered double hydrotalcite was synthesized with a destruction-reconstruction process by referring to the methods illustrated in the literature with some modifications [26] (Fig. S1). Two grams of the NiMgAl-LDH powder was tiled uniformly into a quartz boat, which was placed at the center of a horizontal quartz tube inside a furnace. The sample was heated under an Ar flow (300 mL/min) from ambient temperature to 400 ℃ with a heating rate of 1℃/min and then maintained at 400 ℃ for 1.5 h. After that, the sample was cooled to room temperature under Ar protection. Calcination would lead to the decomposition of CO3 2− and NO3-, which were located in the interlayer space of LDH, and resulted in the destruction of the LDH structure. Then, 0.5 g calcined samples were put into a 0.2 mol/L Na2MoO4 solution, whose pH was adjusted to 10∼12 with a 1 mol/L NaOH aqueous solution, and the LDH structure was reconstructed at 96 ℃ for 24 h. MoO4 2- intercalated LDH would be obtained after filtering, washing, and the freeze-drying process. The collected sample was denoted as NiMgAlMo-LDH. The obtained NiMgAl-LDH and NiMgAlMo-LDH were calcined at 600 ℃ for 3 h with a heating ramp rate of 2 ℃/min to achieve the stable NiMgAl-600 and NiMgAlMo-600 metal oxides for further catalytic evaluation. 2.4 Characterization The specific surface areas and pore structure properties of the catalysts were determined by nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements performed at 77 K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 apparatus. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization of all the samples was performed on an X’pert PRO MPD diffractometer (PANalytical Company, Netherlands) with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA) by recording data from 5° to 85°at a scan speed of 5°/min. The FT-IR spectra were obtained with a BRUKER TENSOR II FTIR spectrometer in the region of 4000–400 cm−1 using KBr pellets. The redox behavior of the catalyst samples was determined by the temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR). The H2-TPR measurement started after the TCD signals stabilized at 50 ℃ under a mixture of 10 vol.% H2/Ar (30 mL/min), and then, the sample was heated from 50 ℃ up to the final isotherm temperature of 1000 ℃ with a heating rate of 3 ℃/min. The temperature programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD) and methane (CH4-TPD) measurements were performed on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument. The H2-TPD and CH4-TPD measurements were performed by placing 0.2 g catalyst sample in the quartz sample tube, which was heated to 800 ℃ under flowing Ar gases and then activated by H2 (30 mL/min, 10 vol.% H2/Ar) for 1 h. After the in-situ reduction of the catalysts, the sample was exposed to an Ar flow and cooled down to 50 ℃ afterwards. H2 (10 vol.% H2/Ar) or CH4 (99.99 %) was then used to induce the catalyst to adsorb the gas molecules, and inert Ar gas was fed into the quartz tube to remove the physically adsorbed molecules. Finally, the TPD profiles were obtained by monitoring the molecule desorption amounts as the catalyst was heated from 50 ℃ to 800 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected by a JEOL JEM-2100 analytical electron microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) characterizations were performed on an FEI G2 instrument. The particle size distributions were determined by evaluating at least 300 particles for each sample. Combined thermogravimetry, differential scanning calorimetry, and mass spectrometry analysis (TG-DSC-MS) was performed under a high purity air-atmosphere by heating from 30 ℃ to 800 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min and using a thermal analysis-quadrupole mass spectrometer manufactured by Netzsch. The Raman spectra of the spent catalysts were obtained at room temperature using a SENTERRA dispersive Raman microscope (Bruker) equipped with a Nd:YAG diode laser with a wavelength of 532 nm, and data were collected from 1000 to 3000 cm−1. 2.5 Catalytic evaluation The activity of the catalysts towards methane decomposition was determined under atmospheric pressure in a continuous downflow vertical fixed-bed reactor (8 mm i.d.), in which 0.2 g of the catalysts (sieved with a 20–40 mesh sieve) were loaded in the isothermal zone of the reactor. Quartz sand (20–40 mesh), which were considered to have a negligible catalytic activity for methane decomposition at the reaction temperature, were used to support the catalyst bed and reduce the dead volume of the reactor. Prior to the reaction, the catalysts were purged with a high purity nitrogen flow for 30 min at the reduction temperature to remove the adsorbed oxygen and water from the catalyst surface. Subsequently, a gas mixture of 10 vol% H2/N2 (50 mL/min) was introduced into the reactor at 800 ℃ for 1 h to reduce the nickel oxide species on each catalyst. The reduced catalysts were denoted as NiMgAl-800 and NiMgAlMo-800. After purging with N2 for another 15 min to eliminate any residual reduction gas, the reactor was cooled to the desired reaction temperature. The reactant gas of methane (99.99 % purity) with no dilution was purged into the reactor to start the methane decomposition reaction at a fixed flow rate of 30 mL/min. The composition of the effluent gaseous products was analyzed by a Scion 456-GC chromatograph equipped with a TCD detector. In previous research, we have found that when using the miniature fixed bed reactor, continuous carbon accumulation blocks the catalyst bed and causes the bed pressure to increase, which to some extent, affect the accuracy of the catalyst activity evaluation. Hence, the catalytic evaluation process would only last for 30 min to ensure the veracity of the catalytic test results. For the reaction-regeneration cycle experiment, the reaction with 30 mL/min pure methane at 650 ℃ proceeded for 6 min to avoid the fragmentation of the catalyst particles as a result of carbon deposition. After that, high-purity N2 was introduced with a 60 mL/min flow rate for 30 min to purge the reactor. Then, 21 % O2/N2 with a flow rate of 40 mL/min was introduced for 15 min into the reactor to burn the carbon deposited on the catalyst. Afterwards, N2 was purged into the reactor again to eliminate the residual oxygen. Finally, 10 vol% H2/Ar was introduced into the reactor with a flow rate of 50 mL/min to reduce the catalyst completely. The reaction-regeneration cycle was repeated 10 times to test the stability of the catalyst. Due to the complete reduction of the nickel species and the high reaction temperature, H2 and CH4 were the only products in the effluent gases, which has been confirmed by the chromatographic analysis results. Hence, the methane conversion ( x C H 4 ) and hydrogen formation rate ( R H 2 ) were calculated using the following equation: (2) x C H 4 % = 1 2 C H 2 1 2 C H 2 + C C H 4 × 100 % where C H 2 and C C H 4 are the concentrations of hydrogen and methane determined by gas chromatography. (3) R H 2 % = F C H 4 × x C H 4 × 2 W c a t × w N i × 100 % where W c a t is the weight of the catalysts in g, F C H 4 is the molar rate of methane conversion in mmol/min, and w N i is the weight percentage of nickel on the catalyst. 2.6 Computational details All the calculations were performed using the DMol3 module of Materials Studio 8.0 (MS) [28]. The module is able to deal with the molecules in the gas phase, the solution, and the solid surface by using density functional theory. The Ni (111), Ni (100), NiMo (111), NiMo (100) surfaces were modeled using a three-layer p (4 × 4) slab comprising 3 metal layers with 16 atoms per layer, and each slab was separated by a vacuum of 20 Åfl to guarantee that the interaction between the neighboring cells was negligible in the z-direction. All the DFT calculations were performed using the CASTEP code, and the exchange-correlation effects were described with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) using the PBE functional proposed by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof. The electron wave functional was expanded by a plane-wave basis set with a cutoff energy of 270 eV. A 3 × 3×1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid was used for the integrations of the Brillouin zone. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the LDHs and calcined samples The NiMgAl-LDH used as the parent hydrotalcite was synthesized by a co-precipitation method using urea as the precipitant, and the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the NiMgAl-LDH sample (Fig. 1 (A-a)) reveals the purity of the samples due to the diffraction lines with relatively high intensities. These belong lines to the rhombohedral layered double hydroxide (ICSD 01-089-0460) with the Mg2+ cations replaced by Ni2+ cations in the brucite layers [23]. The crystal parameter c correlated with the interlayer thickness of brucite can be calculated using c = 3d003 and by considering a 3R symmetry stacking geometry. Parameter c can be regulated by the interlayer water content as well as the size, amount, orientation, and positive charge number of the cations positioned in the brucite layer [29]. The parameter c of NiMgAl-LDH is 2.292 nm, which is similar to that of typical carbonates containing LDHs [30]. To pave the way for the reconstruction process, the NiMgAl-LDH has been calcined at 400 ℃ in an inert atmosphere firstly to remove the CO3 2− and NO3- anions as well as the H2O in the interlayer. As seen from Fig. 1(A-b), the diffraction lines corresponding to the LDHs all disappeared, and the diffraction lines located at 2θ = 37.4°, 43.5°, and 62.9° can be assigned to NiO or a MgNiO2 solid solution [25]. After the calcined sample was reconstructed at 96 ℃ for 24 h, the diffraction lines corresponding to the LDHs appeared again, which illustrates that the reconstructed process occurred successfully, although the relative intensity of these lines is lower than that of the lines observed for the NiMgAl-LDH sample. At the same time, obscured diffraction lines corresponding to metal oxides can also be found, which suggests that the reconstruction process is incomplete. It is clear that the intensity of the characteristic hydrotalcite (006) basal reflections is higher than that of the (003) basal reflection obtained for NiMgAlMo-LDH, which may be due to the variation of the interlayer charge density caused by the introduction of large anions between the layers [31]. The crystal parameters of NiMgAlMo-LDH and NiMgAl-LDH are calculated and presented in Table 1 . The layer thickness of NiMgAlMo-LDH is 0.336 nm and larger than that of NiMgAl-LDH, which can be attributed to the induction of Mo species into the hydrotalcite interlayer. Moreover, the crystal parameter a, which is related to the average distance between the cations inside the hydrotalcite layers, remains unchanged, which implies that the layer compositions did not change after the reconstruction process. To further confirm the existence of Mo species and their form, Raman spectra of the LDH samples were obtained. As depicted in Fig. 2 (a), the spectrum of NiMgAl-LDH exhibits sharp, intense adsorption band at approximately 1051 cm−1, which can be assigned to the symmetric stretching vibrations ν 1 of the incorporated nitrate and carbonate anions [32]. Another band located at 555 cm−1 should be contributed to the Al/Mg-OH translation mode. In terms of the NiMgAlMo-LDH samples, some new adsorption bands emerge. According to the literature [33], the adsorption bands positioned at 320 cm−1, 846 cm-1 and 900 cm-1 can be positively assigned to the monomer MoO4 2- and correspond to the bending, antisymmetric stretching and symmetric stretching modes of the terminal Me = O bond vibrations, respectively. The results also agreed with the literature, in which the polymerization degree of oxymolybdate was shown to be pH dependent, and Mo ions existed as MoO4 2- in an alkaline environment [34]. The visible adsorption band at 555 cm−1, which can be assigned to the lattice vibrations of the brucite octahedral layers, shows the successful recovery of the LDH structure, which agrees with XRD pattern. The presence of such abovementioned signals suggests that the MoO4 2- anions were successfully incorporated into the interlayer of NiMgAlMo-LDH. The FTIR spectra of the LDHs are shown in Fig. 2(b). The bands appearing in the low wavenumber region between 400−1000 cm−1, including those at 553 cm−1, 686 cm−1 and 781 cm−1, can be related to the lattice vibration modes of Me-O in the LDH layers [35]. In addition, a new adsorption band emerges at 1014 cm−1 for the NiMgAlMo-LDH sample, which was not present in the NiMgAl-LDH spectrum. By considering that the MoO4 2- anion was inserted into the hydrotalcite layers, the band attributed to MoO4 2- will shift due to the restriction of the geometric space and the hydrogen bonds between the cation ions and polyoxometalate [36]. Therefore, the bands at 1014 cm−1 can be supposed to correspond to the vibration of the Mo = O bonds in the MoO4 2- species [37], which can also be regarded as an indication that MoO4 2- was incorporated into the structure. Fig. 3 (a) exhibits that the NiMgAlMo-LDH sample displays a predominantly hexagonal lamellar-like morphology, which is typical of Mg-Al hydrotalcite-like compounds [38]. The crystal size of the LDH is approximately 800 nm. For a clearer representation of the LDH structure, TEM has shown the compact packing of multiple layers (Fig. 3(b)). The TEM-EDS elemental mapping images can help to determine the dispersion of each element. As displayed in Fig. 3(c), both the four elements, including Mo, are dispersed homogeneously in the NiMgAlMo-LDH, which provides favorable evidence that the Mo species were successfully intercalated in the LDH interlayer. Based on the abovementioned characterizations, it can be concluded that MoO4 2− was successfully intercalated into the LDH interlayer. Before the catalytic activity of the materials towards the methane cracking reaction was assessed, both the NiMgAl-LDH and NiMgAlMo-LDH samples were calcined at 600 ℃ for 3 h in an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 2 ℃/min. The XRD patterns of the calcined samples are depicted in Fig. 1(B). The main diffraction lines related to NiO (2θ = 37.2°, 43.3°, and 62.8°) are detected for both the two calcined samples. However, it is difficult to exclude the existence of MgNiO2 (2θ = 37.1°, 43.1°, and 62.6°) and the Mg(Al)O periclase phase because these two phases have quite similar diffraction lines locations [23]. Therefore, it is not possible to obtain the NiO particle size by the Scherrer equation. Even so, the lines corresponding to NiO diffractions weakened to some extent as Mo was introduced, which may indicate the increased dispersion of nickel oxide. Invisible MoO3 diffraction lines (2θ = 22.7°, 24.7°, and 26.3°) illustrates the fine dispersion of Mo species after calcination. The physical structures of the as-prepared samples calcined at 600 ℃ were characterized by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms performed at -196 ℃, and the results are exhibited in Fig. S2. As seen from the graph, both the two calcined samples display typical IV isotherms with H1 hysteresis loops, which are generated by the capillary condensation effect and demonstrate the existence of mesopores in all the samples. The physical structural parameters are calculated and shown in Table 2 . The BET surface area and total pore volume of the NiMgAlMo-600 catalyst are smaller than those of the NiMgAl-600 catalyst, the mean pore size of NiMgAlMo-600 (12.8 nm) is larger than that of NiMgAl-600 (7.9 nm), making NiMgAlMo more beneficial to weakening the diffusion resistance of methane molecules. After reduced at 800 ℃ for 1 h, both the reduced catalysts remained the mesoporous structure as shown in Fig. S3. The calculated physical structural parameters were also listed in Table 2. Each of the catalysts endured the decline of surface area and pore volume as well as the increase of mean pore diameter on the contrary. Even so, the surface area of NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst is still smaller than that of NiMgAl-800 and 9.63NiMgAl-800 catalyst. The weight percentage of Ni decreases from 14.34 % in NiMgAl-600 to 9.63 % in NiMgAlMo-600 due to the introduction of Mo, but the Mg/Al molar ratios of the two catalysts remain unchanged, as determined by the results of ICP-AES. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the NiMgAl-800 and NiMgAlMo-800 catalysts The catalytic performance of NiMgAl-800 and NiMgAlMo-800 catalysts towards the methane catalytic cracking reaction was evaluated at 650 ℃, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . Additional 9.63NiMgAl-800 catalyst with the same nickel loading and Mg/Al molar ratio of NiMgAlMo-600 catalyst was also prepared to compare the catalytic activity. The XRD and physical structure properties of this catalyst were involved in Fig. 1 and Table 2. Hydrogen was the only product detected in the reaction gas. Fig. 4(a) displays CH4 conversion as a function of the reaction time. During the 30 min continuous reaction, it is clear that the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst exhibits a higher methane conversion than NiMgAl-800 and 9.63NiMgAl-800 catalysts, as the same trend when the reduction temperature was 850 ℃ (Fig. 4(c)). As mentioned above, introducing Mo has resulted in smaller NiO species on the NiMgAlMo catalyst. Therefore, it can be suggested that the smaller Ni particles that are probably generated after reduction should be responsible for the superior activity. Each of the three catalysts reduced at 800 ℃ possessed a higher methane conversion than the catalysts reduced at 850 ℃ and were deactivated as the reaction went on. A lower reduction temperature could minimize the nickel species sintering and result in smaller nickel particles, which would provide more unsaturated coordination sites for methane activation, thus promoting the catalysis activity. As can be seen in Fig. 4(c), the NiMgAl-850 catalyst pre-reduced at 850 ℃ retained a relatively stable activity of approximately 22 % CH4 conversion, while the NiMgAlMo-850 catalyst reduced at the same temperature performed with a higher CH4 conversion of 39 % after a short induction period and then suffered from a slight deactivation to 26 % at the end of 30 min. Many researchers have indicated that the activity and stability of Ni catalysts during a methane reaction depends strongly on the Ni particle size [39–41]. The decline in the methane conversion with increasing the time on stream can be correlated with the formation of encapsulating carbon, which prevents the methane from contacting the nickel atoms [18,42] and, also, the sintering of the nickel particles [43]. The corresponding H2 formation rates based on the metal content were calculated and are presented in Fig. 4(b) and (d). Previously, to determine whether Mo can activate methane molecules, a MoMgAl-800 catalyst prepared by the same method used to prepare NiMgAlMo-800 but without the addition of Ni was considered as a reference. The methane conversion was below 1% under the same reaction conditions. Thus, the contribution of Mo on the methane activation can be ignored. Therefore, only the nickel contents are used to calculated R H 2 . It is easier to evaluate the effective promotion of the catalytic activity after the introduction of the Mo species. The highest R H 2 of the NiMgAlMo-850 catalyst (52 mmol/gNi min is 3 times higher than that of NiMgAl-850 (18 mmol/gNi min and 1.6 times higher than that of 9.63NiMgAl-850 (32 mmol/gNi min. When the reduction temperature was 800℃, the highest R H 2 of the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst is 1.7 times higher than that of NiMgAl-800 and 1.4 times higher than that of 9.63NiMgAl-800 (56 mmol/gNi min 33 mmol/gNi·min and 40 mmol/gNi·min, respectively). The influence of the reaction temperature on NiMgAl-800 and NiMgAlMo-800 catalysts was evaluated, and the results are also shown in Fig. 5 . The highest R H 2 of both the two catalysts increases with increasing reaction temperatures due to the endothermic property of the methane cracking reaction. The NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst could obtain an excellent hydrogen formation rate of 60.4 mmol/gNi min at the reaction temperature of 700 ℃. At all the reaction temperatures, the initial R H 2 of the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst is much higher than that of the NiMgAl-800 catalyst. The catalytic activity can be maintained during the 30 min reaction for the two catalysts, but more severe deactivation cannot be avoided under high reaction temperatures. For the industrialization of the CDM process, the reactor design and process parameter optimization are of great importance [44]. The CDM process requires either i a single use catalyst that is productive, cheap and abundant enough to be disposed of along with the carbon product or ii a continuous cycle of catalyst coking and regeneration in fluidized, moving or swing bed configurations. A fixed-bed reactor is preferred for option i, and thus, extremely high ratios of carbon laydown to the catalyst weight need to be achieved – far higher than those achieved in this research. Another obstacle of performing a CDM process in a fixed-bed reactor is the difficulty in effectively removing the deposited carbon from the catalyst. Although the fixed-bed reactor has been widely used for CDM processes in laboratory research, it is not suitable for large-scale continuous industrial production. A fluidized-bed reactor can be a suitable candidate, particularly since it enables the constant addition and withdrawal of catalyst particles and offers additional advantages in heat and mass transfer. The CDM process was firstly industrialized as the UOP HYPRO process in 1966. The process was performed in a circulating fluidized bed reactor operated at 977 °C and atmospheric pressure [15]. In a typical procedure, the CDM reaction takes place in a rapid riser to produce high-purity hydrogen, and then, the deactivated catalysts move to the regenerator to recover their catalytic activity. Subsequently, the regenerated catalysts are conveyed back to the rapid riser to complete the reaction loop. In this process, the reaction energy can be compensated by the strong exothermic catalytic regeneration process. Further, additionally syngas can be produced through the selection of a suitable regenerative medium (for example, air, CO2, or H2O) and precisely controlling the regeneration conditions. For the catalysts used in the fluidized bed reactor, a high hydrogen formation rate and good regeneration stability should be of equal importance. The catalytic performances of Ni catalysts recently reported in the literature are compared and visualized in a graph, as shown in Fig. 6 . The mains reaction conditions of these catalysts are listed in Table S1. Both the two main influencing factors of the feed flow velocity and reaction temperature are chosen as the variate in the graph. As shown in Fig. 6, the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst studied in this work exhibits a hydrogen formation rate that is superior to that of most catalysts reported in recently published literature, even though two catalysts with higher hydrogen formation rates have been obtained at reaction temperatures higher than 700 ℃ in this work. Fig. 7 depicted the evolution as a function of the cycle times of the H2 formation rate for NiMgAlMo-800 catalysts undergoing ten successive cycles of CDM/air/hydrogen regeneration. As seen from Fig. 7, after the in-situ regeneration by coke combustion under an air atmosphere and reactivation under hybrid hydrogen, the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst exhibited a performance during the latter nine cycles that was similar to that observed during the first cycle, showing only a small decrease in the H2 formation rate. The results indicated that the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst exhibited an excellent stability during the reaction-regeneration cycles and possessed potential for applications in fluidized bed reactors. 3.3 Investigation of the Mo effect on improving the catalytic activity To uncover the reason that Mo addition improves the catalytic performance, some characterizations were made to establish a correlation between the catalyst structure and activity. To investigate the ability of Mo to change the reducibility of nickel and the metal-support interaction, H2-TPR characterization was carried out on the NiMgAl-600 and NiMgAlMo-600 catalysts. As seen from Fig. 8 (a), for the NiMgAl-600 catalyst, the maximum reduction temperature is shown as a broad band between 550 ℃ and 900 ℃ centered at 735 ℃, indicating the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni°, and this maximum reduction temperature is higher than that observed for bulk NiO at 300 ℃. This finding indicates that a strong interaction exists between the nickel species and the support [45]. Concerning the NiMgAlMo-600 catalyst, two reduction peaks centered at 460 ℃ and 700 ℃ were observed. The low-temperature peak (centered at 460 ℃) can be assigned to the partial reduction (Mo6+ to Mo4+) of amorphous, highly defective, multilayered Mo oxides or heteropolymolybdates (octahedral Mo species). The peak centered at a high temperature (centered at 700 ℃) can be correlated with the simultaneous reduction of Ni2+ to Ni° and the successive reduction of Mo4+ to Mo° [46]. The concomitant reduction of both Mo species and Ni species may lead to a close interaction between Mo and Ni. The peak assigned to the reduction of Ni2+ on the NiMgAlMo-600 catalyst shifts by 35 ℃ to lower temperature, which strong suggests the promotion effect of Mo on Ni2+ reduction through the interaction between the Ni and Mo species. To ascertain the phases of the reduced catalysts, the catalysts reduced at 800 ℃ were characterized by XRD. As displayed in Fig. 8(b), sharp and strong diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 44.5°,51.8°, and 76.3°, which correspond to metallic Ni, are observed in the pattern of NiMgAl-800. The diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 36.8°, 44.7°, and 63.5° can be assigned to the periclase phase of the mixed oxide or NiAl2O4 and spinel MgAl2O4, which were generated under the harsh reduction temperature of 800 ℃, but it is difficult to identify these diffraction peaks because they overlap. With regards to the NiMgAlMo-800 catalysts, some obvious diffraction peaks emerge at the angle of 44.1°, 51.4° and 75.8°. Compared with the diffraction peaks related to Ni (2θ = 44.5°,51.8°, 76.3°), each of the diffraction peaks is all slightly shift to lower 2θ angle and weakened. According to the Bragg equation, diffraction peaks present at smaller 2θ values correspond to larger crystal plane spacings, which can indicate that Mo atoms (atomic radius of 0.136 nm) are incorporated into the Ni (atomic radius of 0.125 nm) crystal planes, forming Ni-Mo alloy particles. The metal particle size of the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst, as calculated by the Scherrer equation for the Ni (200) plane, is 6.3 nm, which is much smaller than nickel particles on the NiMgAl-800 catalyst, whose size is 26.3 nm. The results presented above indicate that the much smaller nanoparticles on the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst most likely exist in the form of Ni-Mo alloys. To confirm the formation of Ni-Mo alloys and estimate the particle sizes on both the catalysts, TEM characterization was performed. The micrograph of the NiMgAl-850 catalyst reduced at 850 ℃ for 1 h shows a substantial number of large Ni particles formed irregularly and with an average size of 52.8 nm, presenting with a broad size distribution (Fig. 9 (a)). The nickel particle size of 9.63NiMgAl-850 is 28.4 nm (Fig. 9(h)). On the other hand, the formation of much smaller particles with a narrow size distribution and an average size of 19.5 nm can be confirmed clearly by the TEM image (Fig. 9(c)) of the NiMgAlMo-850 catalyst. As presented in Fig. 9(e), Fig. 9(f) and (g), small particles with approximately 7.4 nm mean sizes were distributed on the NiMgAlMo-800 catalysts reduced at 800 ℃ for 1 h, while particles with mean sizes of approximately 30.8 nm were present on the NiMgAl-800 catalyst and 17.3 on 9.63NiMgAl-800 catalyst. The crystal structure of the metal particles on the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst was characterized by high-resolution TEM (Fig. 9(i)), which shows clear fringes with spacings of at 0.210 nm corresponding to a face-centered cubic lattice. This lattice distance that is larger than that of unalloyed Ni (111) of 0.204 nm [47] also confirmed the insertion of Mo into Ni, which coincided with the XRD patterns. Meanwhile, the STEM-EDS map of the reduced NiMgAlMo-800 catalysts shown in Fig. 8(j) provides direct evidence that the Ni and Mo elements combine in the metal particles. The results indicate that Mo plays a vital role in forming small NiMo alloy particles, which would lead to a material with a higher catalytic activity. The probable formation process of small NiMo alloy particles is illustrated in Fig. 10 . As already proven, the MoO4 2− species have intercalated into the LDH interlayer, and these Mo species would be transformed into MoO3 after calcination and would still be highly dispersed between the hydrotalcite layers. During the following reduction procedure, the MoO3 species would serve as a “fence” to effectively prevent the sintering of the nickel species located at the adjacent layers, which are inclined to aggregate and cause the hydrotalcite structure to collapse under harsh calcination conditions [26]. The reduced Ni atoms would combine with the simultaneously reduced Mo atoms to generate alloy particles. Additionally, because the melting point of Mo (2620 ℃) is higher than that of Ni (1453 ℃), the Tammann temperature of the NiMo alloy is bound to be higher than that of the pure Ni particles (691 ℃). Thus, Mo addition can also effectively reduce the movability of nickel particles by forming Ni-Mo alloys, leading to a better stability. To further verify the better stability of NiMo alloy particles than nickel particles, both the NiMgAl-600 and NiMgAlMo-600 catalysts were reduced for 12 h at 850 ℃. As clearly illustrated in Fig. 9(b) and (d), the NiMo alloy particles are significantly smaller for the NiMgAlMo-850 catalysts than for the NiMgAl-850 catalyst, regardless of the treatment. The mean particle size of NiMgAlMo-850 increased slightly from 19.5 nm with a 1 h reduction treatment to 26.2 nm with a 12 h reduction treatment but increased from 52.8 nm to 68.5 nm for the NiMgAl-850 catalyst. Additionally, the surface electronic properties were also investigated by DFT calculations to explore if the adsorption properties of the reactants were improved by Mo addition. The low-miller indices (100) and (111) facets of Ni and Ni-Mo were chosen due to the easy exposure of the FCC-type Ni particles, which was confirmed by the high-resolution TEM and FFT characterizations shown in Fig. 9(g) [48]. The Ni/Mo ratio, which was fixed at 4 in the model, was determined by the XPS elemental analysis results shown in Table S2. The chemisorption energy (ΔEads) of the surface methane species on Ni (111), Ni (100), Ni-Mo (111), and Ni-Mo (100) were determined by periodic DFT calculations and calculated as follows: (4) ΔEads=Eadsorbate+surface-Eadsorbate-Esurface In this definition, a more negative chemisorption energy signifies stronger binding between the adsorbate and surface. The typical top, bridge, and hollow adsorption sites were considered for methane adsorption, and only the most stable adsorption configurations are demonstrated in Fig. 11 . The calculated adsorption energy values imply that CH4 adsorption is a physical adsorption process, which agrees with the previous literature [48,49]. The methane molecule prefers to bind on the bridge sites on both the Ni (100) and Ni (111) surfaces but inclined to stay closer to the Mo atoms on the Ni-Mo (100) and Ni-Mo (111) surfaces. The adsorption energy of Ni-Mo (111) (-0.62 eV) and Ni-Mo (100) (-2.77 eV) is larger than that of the relatively pure Ni (111) (-0.15 eV) and Ni (100) (-2.04 eV), which indicates that CH4 adsorbs strongly after Mo addition. CH4-TPD characterization has been carried out and has drawn the same conclusion as the DFT analysis. As shown in Fig. 13(a), the higher desorption temperature of methane indicated the stronger adsorption of methane by the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst. To reveal the reason for the increase in the adsorption ability, the Mulliken charge analysis was performed. As seen from Fig. S4, after the insertion of Mo, electrons were transferred from Mo to Ni, resulting in the surrounding Ni atoms being negatively charged with -0.16 eV∼ -0.18 eV. The electron transfer phenomenon is also proved by the XPS characterization of the NiMgAlMo-800 and NiMgAl-800 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 12 . The XPS peaks located at 856.4 eV are assigned to Ni2+ species [50] and could be generated by the inevitable oxidation of Ni° to Ni2+ in the sample transfer process for the uppermost 6–10 Ni layers [51]. As depicted in Fig. 12, the XPS peak of Ni° located at a binding energy of 853.7 eV shifts to a lower energy of 853.0 eV, which can be attributed to the acceptance of electrons from the Mo atoms. After the adsorption of CH4, the Mulliken charge of the methane molecule was analyzed and is identified in Fig. S5. Compared with the molecules adsorbed on the pure Ni surfaces, the increase in the electron density of the H atoms indicates that the adsorbed methane withdraws more electrons from the Ni-Mo surfaces than from the Ni surfaces. The enhanced electron transfer from the Ni-Mo surface to CH4 resulted in improved reactant adsorption and could hence favor CH4 decomposition. Additionally, the H2-TPD characterization was performed to analyze the desorption property change of the hydrogen produced by Mo insertion. As shown in Fig. 13(b), the hydrogen desorption peak of the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst centered at 107 ℃ occurs at a much lower temperature than that of the NiMgAl-800 catalyst, whose peak position is centered at 216 ℃. The lower desorption temperature indicates that the adsorbed H atoms more easily detach to form the hydrogen product. In conclusion, the stronger adsorption of methane and easier desorption of hydrogen from NiMgAlMo-800 should be responsible for the better catalytic activity for methane cracking in addition to the particle size effect. 3.4 Characterization of the spent catalysts To obtain insight into the nature of the carbon deposits, the spent NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst after ten successive reaction-regeneration cycles were examined by TEM and TG-DSC-MS after methane was decomposed. Fig. 14 (a) shows the TG profiles of spent NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst. Based on the weight loss of 11.2 %, the amounts of the carbon deposits were calculated to be 1.3 gC/gNi. The DSC curve shows a broad exothermic peak, which belongs to the carbon combustion process. Fig. 15 (a) shows the TEM image of regenerated NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst after ten successive reaction-regeneration cycles. The mean size of NiMo particles on the regenerated catalyst was calculated to be 8.7 nm, which was slight larger than on the fresh reduced NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst (7.4 nm). That indicated the good stability of the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst. Fig. 15(b–e) shows the morphology of the carbon deposited on the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst, which shows that the carbon products mainly occur as multi-walled nanotubes (CNTs) in nature. The HRTEM image of the carbon nanotube reveals a layered structure with a metal particle remaining on the top of the filamentous carbon (Fig. 15(c)), exhibiting a high graphitization degree with a d-spacing of 0.34 nm, which agrees with the (002) interplanar distance of graphite. In the case of this carbon deposit, the NiMo particles can retain their exposure of the active plane and maintain their activity during the reaction process [51]. During CDM reaction, the produced carbon atoms may transfer to the metal-support interface by spreading on the surface of metal particle or dissolving into metal particle, then constructed to form nanotubes. As the reaction goes on, continuously migrate carbon atoms promote the carbon nanotubes growth, supports the metal particles on the tip of nanotube [52]. In addition, other different kinds of carbon can be distinguished by a more detailed analysis. The metallic crystal was encapsulated by structured carbon layers to form carbon nano onions (CNOs) with a quasi-spherical morphology (Fig. 15(e)) as well as embedded within the carbon nanotubes (Fig. 15(d)). These two types of carbon couldn’t fully cover the active surface of NiMo particles, As a consequence, the catalyst activity could be maintained. Since the formed NiMo particles were not exactly uniform, the interaction between metal particles and support was different. It is assumed that the strong interaction between some peculiar NiMo particles and support will restrict metal particle movement, result in the formation of encapsulated carbons. Some of that metal particles became narrowed with the growth of nanotubes and the tail of particle were squeezed into the carbon nanotubes, forming encapsulated metal particle in carbon nanotube with diameter the same as the inner diameter of the nanotube [53]. The effluent CO2 gas produced by the carbon oxidation process during the TG analysis was detected by the online mass spectrum, and the intensity plots are deconvoluted by a Gaussian function. As seen in Fig. 14(b), the broad peaks located between 450 ℃∼750 ℃ can be divided into three peaks. Different kinds of carbon species can be identified by combining the TG-MS results with the TEM results. The peaks centered at 626 ℃ and 658 ℃ could be attributed to the oxidation products of CNOs (Cβ) and CNTs (Cγ), respectively. The peak centered at 560 ℃ can be assigned to the oxidation product of amorphous carbon (Cα). This type of carbon fully covered the nickel particles and was responsible for catalyst deactivation as a result of the limited accessibility of reactants on metallic active sites [43]. The percentage of Cα, Cβ and Cγ is calculated to be 21 %, 41 %, 38 %, respectively. The slight deactivation of NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst was due to the exist of amorphous carbon (Cα). 4 Conclusions A MoO4 2−-intercalated NiMgAlMo-LDH was successfully synthesized by taking advantage of the characteristic “memory effect” of hydrotalcite. The as-prepared NiMgAlMo-LDH was used as the catalyst in a methane catalytic decomposition reaction after the LDH material was calcined at 600 ℃. The NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst exhibited a catalytic activity that was superior to that of the NiMgAl-800 catalyst derived from the untreated NiMgAl-LDH under all of the reaction conditions chosen. The influences of the pre-reduction temperature and reaction temperature on the catalytic activity were both investigated. The NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst could achieve an excellent hydrogen formation rate of 60.4 mmol/gNi min at a reaction temperature of 700 ℃. Under ten successive CDM/Air/Hydrogen reaction-regeneration cycles, the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst exhibited good stability for showing a small decrease of H2 formation rate. After analyzing the characterization results, we found that the smaller sintering-free NiMo alloy particles with an average particle size of 7.4 nm formed on the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst under a harsh reduction temperature of 800 ℃. The probable formation route of the small NiMo alloy particles is proposed. The smaller NiMo alloy articles would improve the activity performance not only by the particle size effect but also by enhancing the adsorption of the methane reactant and desorption of the hydrogen product by means of stimulating electron transfer from Mo to Ni. Different kinds of carbon were deposited on the spent NiMgAlMo-800 catalysts, and amorphous carbon led to the activity decrease. The process of intercalating heteropolyacid anions in LDHs provides an effective method for fabricating thermally stable and highly dispersed metal catalysts. We also hope the illustration of the Mo promotion effect on Ni will inspire other researchers to modulate the catalytic activity in the methane conversion reaction. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of highly active and stable Ni catalysts for the catalytic decomposition of methane (CDM) reaction is still a challenge. Herein, a MoO4 2− intercalated NiMgAlMo layered double hydrotalcite (LDH) was synthesized. After calcination and reduction, NiMo alloy particles with an average diameter of 7.4 nm were formed and showed good thermal stability. The NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst showed superior hydrogen formation rate of 56 mmol/gNi min compared with the NiMgAl-800 catalyst of 33 mmol/gNi min derived from NiMgAl-LDH. The stability of the NiMgAlMo-800 catalyst showed good catalytic stability under 10 times reaction-regeneration cycles. With the aid of multiple characterization techniques, we found that Mo addition could not only improve nickel dispersibility but also facilitate methane adsorption and hydrogen desorption through simulative electron transfer from Mo to Ni, thus enhancing the catalyst activity. The insights and methodology presented here may shed new light on the synthesis of highly dispersed and stable metal catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: NiMgAlMo catalyst derived from a guest-host MoO4 2- mediated layered double hydroxide: High performance for the methane decomposition reaction
